Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Design Framework for Biomimetic Elasto-Fluidic Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to formulate a methodology for the design of elasto-fluidic systems (EFSs). EFSs utilize fluid pressure to deform a material envelope with tuned flexibility. They are ubiquitous in nature and may be found in organisms ranging from trees to worms to octopi. These systems achieve a wide range of functionality including desired structure, complex motion, flexibility, and efficient transmission of energy. There are numerous potential applications for elasto-fluidic systems in robots, machines, medical devices, and consumer products. To address the primary goals of the proposed research, it will be necessary to investigate a broad range of technical fields to characterize the salient physical phenomena that govern the behavior of EFSs. The characterization will be utilized in developing a systematic and general method to create EFSs at multiple scales with various materials. The design method will be validated through the design and fabrication of novel proof-of-concept prototypes.

If successful, the broader impacts of the research are extensive. The systematic synthesis of EFSs represents a paradigm shift in mechanical design. EFSs operate on a completely different set of assumptions that facilitate a wider range of functionality and benefits including lower power and maintenance requirements, simplicity and elegance in design, lower long-term cost, and increased precision. These benefits may prove to be far reaching to other fields in engineering. Beyond the impacts of the research on other technical fields, the PI?s have a vested interest in engaging the next generation of engineers at both the high school and undergraduate levels. In collaboration with local high school teachers, the PI?s have will create, implement, assess, and disseminate modules in high school physics courses that integrate mechanical engineering and biologically inspired design. These activities will be made publically available, and their results will be disseminated at educational conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Soft-bodied animals, such as worms, starfish, and octopus lack any skeletal support, yet they can move vigorously and gracefully. Utilizing elasto-fluidic principles of soft-bodied animals, or hydrostats, we developed new methods to create soft robots and other devices that can safely interact with humans and the environment for a variety of industrial and medical applications. 

 

Hydrostats consist of a patterned arrangement of the connective tissue fibers and muscle fibers combined with a liquid filled cavity to generate hydrostatic forces for movement.  The cross-helical arrangement of fibers, which is most commonly found, serves as an antagonist against fluid pressure generated by muscle contraction and determines the range of motion while allowing for equal distribution of forces throughout the hydrostatic body.  A special case of hydrostatic skeleton is a muscular hydrostat, such as arms of octopus and elephant trunks employ a tightly packed array of muscle fibers around a hydrostatic body. Several other types of hydrostats can be found in nature.

 

In this NSF-funded research carried out at the University of Michigan’s Complaint Systems Design laboratory, we employed pressurized fluid (air, water or other liquids) inside a fiber-reinforced elastomeric enclosure (FREE). The FREE is a hollow cylinder of elastic polymer reinforced with two or more layers of fiber mesh. The angles at which the fibers wound around the cylinder determine how the device changes its shape or generates different types of forces and/or motions when the fluid inside is pressurized. Prior to this research only a small subset of such devices were studied. Our research uncovered a wide range of fiber architectures to generate a variety of motions and shapes – ushering in new ways to design and build soft robots. Different classes of FREEs identified in our research serves as building blocks for constructing soft robots. Moreover, as we demonstrated, when different types of FREEs are combined in parallel many more intricate motions can be generated depending on which FREE is pressurized (or actuated). 

 

These new, expanded sets of designs were mathematically modeled to understand the forces, motions, and shapes they could create. Motions including pure translation, pure rotation, combination of translation and rotation (screw motion), bending in three dimensions, and helical motions were all mathematically modeled. Hundreds of prototypes were built and experimentally tested to verify that our mathematical and computational models could be used to predict the overall behavior. Computational and visual design tools were created to assist others in utilizing this new technology in their designs. This project uncovered an entire design space of artificial hydrostats and developed design tools, opening a wealth of possibilities to create better and never before possible engineered solutions to a wide array of problems.

 

Applications of newly discovered FREEs range from soft, user-friendly (arm and leg) orthosis devices and minimally invasive surgery, to dexterous factory-line robots, utilizing readily available pressurized air, capable of handling fragile items that today’s robots cannot. Our team has been working with collaborators from industry and hospitals to explore real-world applications and is seeking new collaborations.

 

Our collaborators at Bucknell University, Dr. Kim and his students led outreach efforts to Kelly Elementary School where third grade students were introduced to 3D printing and mechanical design. Elementary students participated in a "mechanical dissection" activity where they took apart household appliances, identified key components, and presented their findings to their classmates.
